questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online subscription that uses a namespace of litwareinc.com.
You create a connector in Exchange Online that is configured as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: Tested in lab, validated the answers given are correct

The TlsDomain parameter specifies the domain name that the Outbound connector uses to verify the FQDN of the target certificate when establishing a TLS secured connection. This parameter is only used if the TlsSettings parameter is set to DomainValidation.
The TlsSettings parameter specifies the TLS authentication level that's used for outbound TLS connections established by this Outbound connector. Valid values are:
• EncryptionOnly: TLS is used only to encrypt the communication channel. No certificate authentication is performed.
• CertificateValidation: TLS is used to encrypt the channel and certificate chain validation and revocation lists checks are performed.
• DomainValidation: In addition to channel encryption and certificate validation, the Outbound connector also verifies that the FQDN of the target certificate matches the domain specified in the TlsDomain parameter.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/new-outboundconnector?view=exchange-ps
Correct
correct answer

comments.content: If A is correct, D is also a feasible choice to verify whether the account is synced. IMO, the NDR saying user not found, means this user isn't available in cloud. The next step is to verify whether this account is synced or not in AAD Connect.
I would agree with jejechu. The answer should be A, if you want to know the cause of the error.
but users can exchange mails in server1 , so user health state and mailbox is good so it must be synchro issue ! so its D !

discussion.content: I think the answer is A. I would check first on EXO Admin Center if user1 appears as a Mail User. If not, I would check AD Connect and launch a delta sync if everything is correct with the synced OUs

In a real world scenario, both answers A and C would be viable. Is completely natural to search in the EAC first to see if the mail user is there, and if not, then move to check if there is any problem with the synchronization of the user. But we can only choose one, and the question states that "User1 was not found" from the NDR message. With this information it is redundant to check the EAC for the User1, because if a mail user exists in Exchange Online for User1 the NDR message should not be the one mentioned. So choosing just one, i would point directly to a sync for user1 as the cause of the error.
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Since it's a new mailbox that has just been created on On-Prem Server1, it's a synch issue!

Selected Answer: C
User doesn't exist in 365/Azure, gotta check the reason il AD Connect Health

Selected Answer: A
Its Correct

Selected Answer: C
new user not synced yet
04/16/2022 - on the exam
I had this issue, where AD Connect was not synching after server was upgraded from Server 212 to Server 216, so I know for sure its caused by AD Connect health
3/24/2022 - on the exam

Selected Answer: C
The description says: "On Server1, you create a new mailbox that uses an email address of user1@contoso.com", so mailbox is already created on-prem and you need to check if it is synched to the cloud.
exam dated 26-jan-22

Selected Answer: C
since its on-premise mailbox, it needs to be sync with Azure before exchange online users can send the email to it. i would go with C

Selected Answer: C
of course checking if the user appears on exo admin center would be the first thing that most of people would do but they are looking for WHERE IS THE PROBLEM that it seems to be on ad connect.

Agreed its an ambiguous scenario question, but the clue is:
- mail-flow is working for all other users
- mailbox was recently created and the NDR is unique to this user
- The NDR actually says the user can't be found which is typically a directory AD issue

Best answer is C based on information provided.
Braindump2 says A

If a recipient is not found, i would say i would go to EAC first on exchange online and search for it. I dont know if that is the best way to do it, but that is what i do first all the time. That is the first thing that comes to my mind.

In practice, checking the user in the EAC Admin Center would be a reasonable first action but being as the user is receiving email successfully from other on premise users, I would assume the user is setup correctly and should sync successfully to Exchange Online, therefore I agree C is probably the best answer as the Sync may be the issue.

comments.content: Sorry. if the user can send from Exchange online, it is licensed. Even so I still think that the exchange administrator is the best tool, since it has been able to synchronize with the user domain / user1, or it can be a mailuser, both errors are verifiable in the Exchange online EAC

Users on prem don't need to be licensed. So not a licensing concern. If the mailbox exists and the object is synced it would get there. My gut is also C is correct and explanation is plausible - but to be honest I would probably look in EAC first and then scratch my head and move over and find the issue in azure ad connect health.

discussion.content: A. It may be the case that the user does not have an assigned license. This error was not detected by azure ad connect. Going to the exchange administrator can give us clues since it does not have a license, it does not appear as a mailbox, although it is well synchronized with Azure AD
Answer:- A

comments.content: As the error is self explanatory "User1 wasn't found at contoso.com." so why you again going to console to check if user exist or not. It is for sure user is not there so check the replication. Given answer is correct i think.

The question states "You need to identify what causes the email delivery to fail". As you stated, the EAC will only show you if user1@contoso.com exists within it. We need to know why that is the case. Answer C is the answer to the why.

discussion.content:
A
You will first need to validate if the user mailbox can be found in online EAC. If it cannot be found, then either the mailbox is not provisioned properly, or it is not synced properly or not even synced at all. Then you will go AAD admin center to see if the user is there, if it is there then go to AAD Connect Health to check if there are any sync errors. Incorrect AAD sync can cause the mailbox to be in the wrong provisioned state and causes NDR.
B: This is the on-prem exchange so it would not have the answer for sure. 
C\D: Although this is possible this would not be the first step.

Answer C is plausible. 

Mailbox is created on Server1 (on-prem).
"Users hosted on Server1 can send email to user1@contoso.com successfully"
So Mailbox definitely exists.
I would therefore check, if the synchronization was successful.

comments.content: according to a payed braindump A should be the right answer.
It could be an issue with the synchronization of the Identity from AD to Azure AD.

discussion.content:
"You verify that the Exchange Online users can send email successfully to the other mailboxes hosted on Server1. Users hosted on Server1 can send email to user1@contoso.com successfully." So it cant be a replication delay. 
C is the wrong answer. I would go with A

choices.D: the Azure Active Directory admin center

questions.question_text:
You have a hybrid deployment that contains a Microsoft Exchange Online tenant and an on-premises Exchange Server 2019 server named Server1. All users use an email address suffix of @contoso.com.
On Server1, you create a new mailbox that uses an email address of user1@contoso.com.
Users hosted in Exchange Online report that they receive a non-delivery report (NDR) when they attempt to send email messages to user1@contoso.com. The
NDR contains the following text: `User1 wasn't found at contoso.com.`
You verify that the Exchange Online users can send email successfully to the other mailboxes hosted on Server1. Users hosted on Server1 can send email to user1@contoso.com successfully.
You need to identify what causes the email delivery to fail.
What should you use?

discussion.content:
Wow the old winmail.dat issue! Now there's a blast from the past!

D all the way!
D is correct
D: had to set this one up in real-life

ON exam - 4/18/2022
All 3 case studies were also on exam
On the test Nov 3,2021
Agreed, answer is correct
Answer:- D
Check it in live environment, answer is correct.

More Info:
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/290809/how-e-mail-message-formats-affect-internet-e-mail-messages-in-outlook
That is the correct answer
Additional info: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/2487954/how-to-specify-the-email-message-format-that-s-used-for-external-recip

choices.D: Configure a remote domain that has the TNEFEnabled parameter set to $False.
choices.B: Create an Outbound connector that has the ValidationRecipients parameter set to contoso.com.
choices.C: Configure a remote domain that has the TrustedMailOutboundEnabled parameter set to $False.
choices.A: Create an Outbound connector that has the ValidationRecipients parameter set to fabrikam.com.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online tenant named contoso.com.
Several users report that email messages sent to the users at another company named fabrikam.com contain a Winmail.dat attachment.
You need to prevent the fabrikam.com users from receiving Winmail.dat attachments.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
Correct anwser is A and B.
Get-MessageTrace only returns mails from last 10 days. 

"To search for message data that is greater than 10 days old, use the Start-HistoricalSearch and Get-HistoricalSearch cmdlets."

comments.content: Agree, reference to support the answer https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/get-messagetrace?view=exchange-ps#description
That's correct, The answer is A & B

discussion.content:
Answer, run a message trace from security and compliance center https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/message-trace-scc?view=o365-worldwide
Run a message trace from EAC https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/monitoring/trace-an-email-message/run-a-message-trace-and-view-results#view-message-trace-results-for-messages-more-than-7-days-old
A and B is correct answer

Selected Answer: AB
Correct anwser is A and B.

Selected Answer: AB
A: Since we have an option in S&C Admin Center to run a message trace (Normally a redirection to ECP). 
B: Regular Message Trace.
Message trace these days is in M365D portal...but really only as a link to Exchange admin center...still, if past is prologue the legacy answers would apply

Selected Answer: AB
Correct anwser is A and B.
A and B are correct.
on exam 11-27-21

I do this a lot. A and B. get-messagetrace cannot show more than 10days. If you run this command and you put a start date that is more than 10days ago, there will be an error and will return no results. 

The correct command to trace emails that are more that 10 days ago is Start-HistoricalSearch and Get-HistoricalSearch. else, use the admin portal either S&C or Exchange admin center.
A&B are the good answers I think

I select Security & Compliance admin center and Exchange admin center.
Get-MessageTrace is limited to 7 days.

Start-HistoricalSearch will allow you to search the full 90 days.
https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/ce0252af-fec7-40e5-8935-1dbe70ee4fe1/getmessagetrace-look-back-period?forum=onlineservicesexchange

this is what appears in the MS-203 official book:
For example, to perform the same search for messages sent by don@adatum.com in a specific time interval, you would run the following cmdlet:
Get-MessageTrace -SenderAddress “don@adatum.com” ‘
-StartDate “01/08/2019 10:00:00” ‘
-EndDate “01/09/2019 11:00:00”
Note: There is often a delay of 5 to 30 minutes before message trace information is available after a message is sent. This applies to both the EAC and Windows PowerShell.

discussion.content: Correct answer should be A and B since you need to search for 30 days trace. You can use Get-MessagetraceDetail and Get-MessageTrace to search message data for the last 10 days. If you enter a time period that's older than 10 days, you will receive an error and the command will return no results.
Answer:- A,B

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/get-messagetrace?view=exchange-ps.

This is a URL that works the one on the Question doesn't
The answer A is also wrong as you can't export failed messages from the Security & Compliance admin center

comments.content:
Yes you can. If you select the time range for more then 10 days you get this message: 
If you choose a time range of more than 10 days, you'll only be able to view the results in a downloadable CSV file. So A is correct.

discussion.content:
According to that link

'Message trace is available in the Microsoft 365 security center and in the modern Exchange admin center.'

comments.content: messagetracedetail is for specific messages not a user
I've changed my mind as they are migrating message trace away from the compliance centre. Answer is B&E
Following on from this it should be A&B as PowerShell can only return results up to 10 days

choices.C: From Exchange Online PowerShell, run the Get-MessageTrace cmdlet.
choices.B: From the Exchange admin center, run a message trace.
choices.D: From the Security & Compliance center, export the mailbox audit logs.
choices.E: From Exchange Online PowerShell, run the Get-MessagetraceDetail cmdlet.
choices.A: From the Security & Compliance center, run a message trace.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online subscription.
You need to generate a CSV file containing all the email messages that failed to send from the user1@contoso.com email address during the last 30 days.
What are two possible ways to achieve the goal? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online tenant that uses an email domain named contoso.com.
You need to prevent all users from performing the following tasks:
✑ Sending out-of-office replies to an email domain named fabrikam.com.
✑ Sending automatic replies to an email domain named adatum.com.
The solution must ensure that all the users can send out-of-office replies and automatic replies to other email domains on the internet.
Solution: You create one mail flow rule.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: remote domain is the key

ON exam - 4/18/2022
All 3 case studies were also on exam
exam dated 26-jan-22
on exam 11-27-21
yes, remote domain would be a solution
Correct, you need to create a remote domain
